newsitem.title: UK: Ex-chancellor Clarke says no need for UK budget.
newsitem.headline: Ex-chancellor Clarke says no need for UK budget.

text.p: There is no economic need for a UK budget on Wednesday because the public finances are in good shape, Kenneth Clarke, former chancellor of the exchequer (finance minister) for the ousted Conservative Party, told BBC radio on Tuesday.
"There's no need for a budget at all. In fact the public finances are in a better state than I expected," he said. "This is to do with politics -- this is getting elected for a second term."

Gordon Brown, chancellor for the Labour government which won the May 1 election after 18 years in opposition, is due to hold a budget on Wednesday at which he is expected to announce tax rises of four billion stg or more.
Clarke said that Brown's aim was to control spending and put up taxation now "when he doesn't need to".
"Later in the parliament he will put spending up without raising taxation and he thinks that's a clever way of getting back for a second term," Clarke said.
But he warned that a higher tax burden would slow down the economy. "He's going to deliver an economy that grows slower, unemployment that doesn't fall so fast."
Some financial experts argue that Brown must raise taxes in the UK to prevent the exuberant consumer sector from pushing the economy into an unsustainable boom.
But others say that fiscal policy is a blunt tool for demand management and say that interest rates should be allowed to take the strain.

There is speculation that the Bank of England will raise Britain's 6.5 percent official interest rates again next week following a surge in consumer spending and borrowing. Consumers are set to receive a financial boost totalling 30 billion stg from building society mergers and flotations.
